section.title: Obligation and permission in the present
section.sectiontitle: We use must, have to and have got to + verb to talk about something that is necessary or important.
section.text1: We often use must in formal written notices:
section.text2: We often use have to or have got to in speaking:
section.text2a: I've got to find a telephone – it's urgent.
section.sectiontitle2: The meaning is usually the same but we often use must when the obligation comes from the speaker and have to or have got to when the obligation comes from someone else.
section.text4a: All young men have to do military service.

section.title: Obligation and permission in the present
section.sectiontitle: In the negative, we use do not have to and have not got to + verb to talk about something that is not necessary. We usually use the short form.
section.text1: It isn't necessary for people to vote.
section.text1a: People don't have to vote if they don't want to.
section.text2: It isn't necessary for him to be there until ten.
section.text2a: He hasn't got to be there until ten.
section.sectiontitle2: In the question, we usually use Do + subject + have to + verb and Have + subject + got to + verb. We don't usually use Must I?

section.title: Obligation and permission in the present
section.sectiontitle: We use can and be allowed to + verb to talk about things we are permitted to do.
section.text1: You are permitted to park here after 6.30 p.m.
section.text2: It's okay for my brother to stay out until 11 o'clock.
section.text2a: My brother's allowed to stay out until 11 o'clock.
section.sectiontitle2: We use must not, be not allowed to, cannot + verb to talk about things which we are not permitted to do. We usually use the short form when speaking.
section.text3a: Members of the audience must not take photographs.
section.text4: Eating in the library is prohibited (not okay)
section.text4a: You're not allowed to eat in the library.

section.title: Obligation and permission in the present
section.sectiontitle: We use should and ought to + verb to say something is a good idea, or that it is right. We often use it for giving advice or making suggestions.
section.text1a: You should try this ice cream – it's delicious.
section.sectiontitle2: In the negative and questions, ought to is not common. In the negative, we use should not + verb and in the question, we use should + subject + verb.
